messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
messages.msgSnippet: Spectacular? Not sure I would go that far but they sure make it easier to come back to the bay area... -t
messages.messageBody:
Spectacular?
Not sure I would go that far but they sure make it easier to
come back to the bay area...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
messages.msgSnippet: Good to run into you, Tom, in the world outside the Net.  Cary s study sessions are pretty spectacular, aren t they? ... From: tom helm To:
messages.messageBody:
Good to run into you, Tom, in the world outside the Net. Cary's study sessions are pretty spectacular, aren't they?

----- Original Message -----
From: tom helm
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, June 23, 2003 11:43 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha


>As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary's study group
>were tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade.Åz
>ÅzÅzÅz
David-
I was the guy who tossed out ububa at the Kenkyukai, nice to meet you
BTW, however I was highly mistaken in my kantei. Cary explained that
this "ububa" was the result of Fujishiro Sensei restoring the hamachi
as part of the overall polish and restoration. When we normally see
this it is on new blades, often on Shinshinto...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
messages.msgSnippet: Re retempered blades getting papers, there is at least one Juyo saiba blade, it is signed Chikamura Tatematsuru , its existence proved that the famous Sanjo
messages.messageBody:
Re retempered blades getting papers, there is at least one Juyo saiba blade,
it is signed 'Chikamura Tatematsuru', its existence proved that the famous
Sanjo Munechika blade signed 'Munechika Murakami' was made by his pupil
Chikamura and had the 'mune' added later. 'kami' and 'tatematsuru' being the
same kanji.

Alan

:

different

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
messages.msgSnippet: As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary s study group were tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade.  I wanted to inquire, but the
messages.messageBody:
As a matter of fact, the older and wiser crowd at Cary's study group were tossing the term around about a Kamakura blade. I wanted to inquire, but the discussion moved on, and I didn't get a chance. I made a note of the term to look it up, and found Hawley's definition, which applied to a sword I have at home.

I think the definition you have provided is more likely what Cary and the gang were talking about, though obviously odd in the case of such an old sword. Thanks for the information.


----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, June 23, 2003 8:23 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha


David,
I don't think there are different forms... it's a short section of "unsharpened" edge just above the hamachi. It's not unusual with gendaito, but is rather rare in older blades. It is ground away as the blade is polished over time.

Very old and very good saiha swords that are otherwise intact can sometimes get kanteisho.

Hopefully someone more knowledgeable about swords can comment.

Jim


Can anyone think of any publications featuring illustrations of different
forms of ubuha?

Do retempered swords ever receive papers?



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ubuha
messages.msgSnippet: David, I don t think there are different forms... it s a short section of unsharpened edge just above the hamachi.  It s not unusual with gendaito, but is
messages.messageBody:
David,
I don't think there are different forms... it's a short section of "unsharpened" edge just above the hamachi. It's not unusual with gendaito, but is rather rare in older blades. It is ground away as the blade is polished over time.

Very old and very good saiha swords that are otherwise intact can sometimes get kanteisho.

Hopefully someone more knowledgeable about swords can comment.

Jim


Can anyone think of any publications featuring illustrations of different
forms of ubuha?

Do retempered swords ever receive papers?



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
